Dr. Bowman Has Had Wide
And Varied Career In Science, Politics; Is Canadian

The abundance of potential reserves
on the Maryland squad makes it
necessary for the varsity five to play
their best ball at all times to retain
their exalted positions. The ability of
the reserves to come through in a
pinch has been one of the essential
factors in the Terps successful campaign.
Waters and Andorka will undoubtedly start in the forward positions. They team up well and form
a dangerous combination. Among the
finest scorers in the state, Waters
is one of the mainstays of the Old
Liners' offense. Slippery and cagey,
he will be a hard man to hold.
Andorka plays a hard, rugged style
of ball. An excellent feeder, he is also
capable of breaking through the defense of the opposition for scores. g
Willis will probably fill the pivot
job. Because of his height, the big
centerman will be of great value to
the Terps on the tap-off and under
the basket.
Buscher and Guckeyson will handle
the defense. Both, veterans, are difficult men to elude. Quick to anticipate

Chairman Announce
Soph Banquet Plans
Murphy Names Nine Sophomores
On Committee; Promises
Beer, Entertainment
Brian Murphy, chairman of the
Sophomore Banquet Committee, revealed his first few plans and announced the committee for the annual
class social function last Thursday.
The committee named by Murphy
Includes Julian Cohen, Gerald Branower, Hershner, Cross, John Crarming,
Thomas Dukehart, David Erck, Paul
hemp, William Matheson and William O'Brian.
In discussing the banquet, Murphy
said:
"We aim to make this banquet 100
Per cent better than last year. An
attempt is now being made to secure
talented amusement that really will
entertain the fellows and not merely
fill up time.
"The dinner will be held at one of
the finest hotels. As soon as James
Alexander gives a statement as to
the treasury situation of the SophoMore Class, I shall take immediate
action."
.Members of the Sophomore Class
Will be secretly informed as to the
date, time, and place of the affair.
Several kegs of beer are to be supPlied along with the entertainment.

Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president-elect
of the Johns Hopkins University, is a
Canadian by birth and has enjoyed
an extensive scientific and political
career. At present a resident of New
York City, Dr. Bowman is expected
to come here during the early part of
March.

Dr. Isaiah Bowman was chosen by
the trustees of the University to succeed Dr. Joseph S. Ames, it was announced by Daniel Willard, president
of the Board of Trustees, at Commemoration Day exercises held Iasi
Friday in the Peabody Institute.

Debaters Practice
For Spring Meets
Practice Debate Held Last Night In
Office of Dr. Clifford P.
Lyons
The Johns Hopkins debating team
held a practice debate yesterday
evening in the office of Dr. Clifford
P. Lyons, coach of the team.
Two three-man teams were formed
to debate the question, "Resolved:
That the nations of the world shall
agree to prohibit the international
shipment of arms and munitions."
The negative side of the question
was upheld by James Morrow, J. S.
Sfekas, and William Garfunkel. The
affirmative was upheld by Philip
Grossman, Abner Willen, president of
the Debating Council, and Sylvan
Garfunkel, secretary.
A debate is to be held with Mount
Saint Mary's on March 4.

Conference At "Y"
Invitations have been issued to students of the Johns Hopkins and University of Maryland Medical Schools
to attend a conference held this evening at the Central Y. M. C. A.

NURSE IN 25th YEAR AT HOSPITAL
Miss Elsie M. Lawler Principal Of School of Nursing And
Superintendent Of Nursing, Came To Johns Hopkins
In 1910; Was Honored At Commemoration Exercises

When Miss Elsie M. Lawler, superintendent of nursing and principal of
the School of Nursing at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, received an honorary Master of Arts degree at Commeration Day exercises, it marked
the twenty-fifth year in which she
has occupied her present positions.
She was graduated from the Hopkins School of Nursing thirty-five
years ago and in 1910 became associated with the hospital.
Awarded M. A. Degree
"In recognition of her outstanding
work in the field of nursing," the
trustees of the University decided to
award her the honorary degree.
Whenever nursing authorities of
the state and nation meet, Miss
Lawler is certain to be a representative from the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
She was president of the Maryland
State Nurses Association for a number of years.
A trustee of the National League
of Nursing Education, she is on the

Freshman Meeting
A meeting of the Freshman
Class will be held Thursday in
Latrobe 120 at 11:30. There will be
no regular assembly and William
C. McClean, president of the Student Council, will address the class.
It is compulsory that every freshman attend this meeting, McClean
said today.

Nurse For 35 Years
Nursing has practically filled the
life of Miss Lawler as she held executive nursing positions in the
Toronto General Hospital and in hospitals in Niagara Falls and Pittsburgh before 'coming to the HopTtIns.
Miss Lawler is a Canadian by birth.
She became "an American by adoption" and is now a nationalized citizen of the United States.
Of her career Miss Lawler seems
reluctant to talk. She is tall, grayhaired and business-like in manner
and speech, and resides at the Hospital.
Since she has been at the Johns
Hopkins, the Harriet-Lane, Winner,
Phipps, Brady and Women's Clinics
have been established.

"Y" Has Speakers
The first in a series of dinner meetings given by the Johns Hopkins Y.
M. C. A. was given last night in Levering Hall.
The speakers were Dr. John J. Russell of St. Martin's Catholic Church.
Dr. Edward L. Israel of Har Sinai
Temple, and Dr. T. Guthrie Speers of
3rown Memorial Presbyterian Church.
The dinner committee is composed
of Carson G. Frailey, Brian Murphy,
Jerome Hurwitz and Henry H. Leber.
The committee is trying to arrange
regular meetings where the students
will hear topics of their choice discussed by leading authorities.

The playoffs for the school handball championship started yesterday
and will continue until March 1.
In the first round N. Finkelstein
will meet J. Eppler, the winner to
play M. Kramer in the second round.
H. Goldberg will compete against H.
Kropman, and G. Kostant will be
matched against the victor. Also L.
Blumenthal and B. Prager will be
pitted against each other, while the
winner will play R. Pasternak. The
final match of the first round will be
between R. Fertig and N. Hackerman.
The victor of this game will meet A.
Glantz in the second round.
Other second round matches bring
together I. Benton and J. Leitch, T.
Wieke and J. Hernandez, and J. Krell
and R. Byer. These players, having
received byes in the first round, play
for the first time in the second round.

The abundance of potential reserves
on the Maryland squad makes it
necessary for the varsity five to play
their best ball at all times to retain
their exalted positions. The ability of
the reserves to come through in a
pinch has been one of the essential
factors in the Terps successful campaign.
Waters and Andorka will undoubtedly start in the forward positions. They team up well and form
a dangerous combination. Among the
finest scorers in the state, Waters
is one of the mainstays of the Old
Liners' offense. Slippery and cagey,
he will be a hard man to hold.
Andorka plays a hard, rugged style
of ball. An excellent feeder, he is also
capable of breaking through the defense of the opposition for scores. g

job. Because of his height, the big
centerman will be of great value to
the Terps on the tap-off and under
the basket.

Brian Murphy, chairman of the
Sophomore Banquet Committee, revealed his first few plans and announced the committee for the annual
class social function last Thursday.
The committee named by Murphy
Includes Julian Cohen, Gerald Branower, Hershner, Cross, John Crarming,
Thomas Dukehart, David Erck, Paul
hemp, William Matheson and William O'Brian.
In discussing the banquet, Murphy
said:
"We aim to make this banquet 100
Per cent better than last year. An
attempt is now being made to secure
talented amusement that really will
entertain the fellows and not merely
fill up time.
"The dinner will be held at one of
the finest hotels. As soon as James
Alexander gives a statement as to
the treasury situation of the SophoMore Class, I shall take immediate
action."

Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president-elect
of the Johns Hopkins University, is a
Canadian by birth and has enjoyed
an extensive scientific and political
career. At present a resident of New
York City, Dr. Bowman is expected
to come here during the early part of
March.

Dr. Isaiah Bowman was chosen by
the trustees of the University to succeed Dr. Joseph S. Ames, it was announced by Daniel Willard, president
of the Board of Trustees, at Commemoration Day exercises held Iasi

Debaters Practice
For Spring Meets
Practice Debate Held Last Night In
Office of Dr. Clifford P.
Lyons
The Johns Hopkins debating team
held a practice debate yesterday
evening in the office of Dr. Clifford
P. Lyons, coach of the team.
Two three-man teams were formed
to debate the question, "Resolved:
That the nations of the world shall
agree to prohibit the international
shipment of arms and munitions."
The negative side of the question
was upheld by James Morrow, J. S.
Sfekas, and William Garfunkel. The
affirmative was upheld by Philip
Grossman, Abner Willen, president of
the Debating Council, and Sylvan
Garfunkel, secretary.
A debate is to be held with Mount
Saint Mary's on March 4.

Conference At "Y"
Invitations have been issued to students of the Johns Hopkins and University of Maryland Medical Schools
to attend a conference held this evening at the Central Y. M. C. A.

NURSE IN 25th YEAR AT HOSPITAL
Miss Elsie M. Lawler Principal Of School of Nursing And
Superintendent Of Nursing, Came To Johns Hopkins
In 1910; Was Honored At Commemoration Exercises

When Miss Elsie M. Lawler, superintendent of nursing and principal of
the School of Nursing at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital, received an honorary Master of Arts degree at Commeration Day exercises, it marked
the twenty-fifth year in which she
has occupied her present positions.
She was graduated from the Hopkins School of Nursing thirty-five
years ago and in 1910 became associated with the hospital.
Awarded M. A. Degree
"In recognition of her outstanding
work in the field of nursing," the
trustees of the University decided to
award her the honorary degree.
Whenever nursing authorities of
the state and nation meet, Miss
Lawler is certain to be a representative from the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
She was president of the Maryland
State Nurses Association for a number of years.
A trustee of the National League
of Nursing Education, she is on the

Nursing has practically filled the
life of Miss Lawler as she held executive nursing positions in the
Toronto General Hospital and in hospitals in Niagara Falls and Pittsburgh before 'coming to the HopTtIns.
Miss Lawler is a Canadian by birth.
She became "an American by adoption" and is now a nationalized citizen of the United States.
Of her career Miss Lawler seems
reluctant to talk. She is tall, grayhaired and business-like in manner
and speech, and resides at the Hospital.
Since she has been at the Johns
Hopkins, the Harriet-Lane, Winner,
Phipps, Brady and Women's Clinics
have been established.

"Y" Has Speakers
The first in a series of dinner meetings given by the Johns Hopkins Y.
M. C. A. was given last night in Levering Hall.
The speakers were Dr. John J. Russell of St. Martin's Catholic Church.
Dr. Edward L. Israel of Har Sinai
Temple, and Dr. T. Guthrie Speers of
3rown Memorial Presbyterian Church.
The dinner committee is composed
of Carson G. Frailey, Brian Murphy,
Jerome Hurwitz and Henry H. Leber.
The committee is trying to arrange
regular meetings where the students
will hear topics of their choice discussed by leading authorities.

The playoffs for the school handball championship started yesterday
and will continue until March 1.
In the first round N. Finkelstein
will meet J. Eppler, the winner to
play M. Kramer in the second round.
H. Goldberg will compete against H.
Kropman, and G. Kostant will be
matched against the victor. Also L.
Blumenthal and B. Prager will be
pitted against each other, while the
winner will play R. Pasternak. The
final match of the first round will be
between R. Fertig and N. Hackerman.
The victor of this game will meet A.
Glantz in the second round.
Other second round matches bring
together I. Benton and J. Leitch, T.
Wieke and J. Hernandez, and J. Krell
and R. Byer. These players, having
received byes in the first round, play
for the first time in the second round.
